reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely important support for the paper’s “mostly-great futures are rare” intuition: the Section 2.4 move from “many possible flaws” to a strongly skewed value distribution via an independent multiplicative toy model. If that step were badly undermined, the argument’s intuitive backbone weakens, though the overall position also rests on other strands (historical moral catastrophe examples; and especially the later Section 3 ‘fussy moral views’ analysis), so it wouldn’t fully collapse. The objection has moderate force: correlations/latent variables (institutional quality, epistemics, value convergence) could indeed make high scores co-occur and reduce the degree of fragility predicted by an independence model. However, it doesn’t show that plausible correlation structures actually make mostly-great futures common, nor that remaining downside isn’t still dominated by a few high-impact correlated failure modes; the paper can also reply that it only claimed “relatively independent” factors and used the model illustratively. Most statements in the critique are correct and well-posed, it’s clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Correlated moral dimensions make mostly-great futures less rare than the product model claims
